html:
For a Reuters live blog on U.S., UK and European stock markets, click LIVE/ or type LIVE/ in a news window.

  • Zillow jumps on upbeat sales
  • Under Armour down after margin warning
  • All three indexes head for weekly gains
  • Indexes: Dow up 0.4%, S&P adds 0.1%, Nasdaq falls 0.1%

Updates to open

By Bansari Mayur Kamdar

Feb 11 (Reuters) - Wall Street's main indexes were mixed on Friday as investors digested hot inflation data that caused a sharp selloff in the previous session on fears about quicker interest rate hikes.

Eight of the 11 major S&P 500 indexes advanced, with energy stocks .SPNY rising 1.8%, helped by an uptick in crude prices after the International Energy Agency (IEA) said oil markets were tight. O/R

Banks .SPXBK also rose 0.9%, but technology .SPLRCT and consumer discretionary .SPLRCD indexes, which include some high-growth names including Amazon AMZN.O and Microsoft MSFT.O, slipped.

The S&P 500 and the Dow fell more than 1% on Thursday, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq slumped 2% after data showed consumer prices surged 7.5% in January, marking the biggest annual increase in 40 years. (Full Story)

Further, St. Louis Fed Bank President James Bullard, a voter on the Fed's rate-setting committee this year, told Bloomberg News on Thursday he wants a full percentage point of rate hikes over the next three policy meetings. (Full Story)

"We've got some element of calm coming into the market, that's the digestion of the news," said Seeema Shah, chief strategist at Principal Global Investors.

"The Fed doesn't want to send an alarm signal, they want to look like they have a stable grip on the situation, and not send everyone running around."

The inflation data and subsequent comments from Bullard drove investors to ramp up bets of rate hikes this year.

Traders are pricing in a big half-point rate hike in March with just a scant chance of a smaller quarter-point hike, and heavy bets for a policy path that would bring rates to a range of 1.75%-2.00% by the end of the year. (Full Story) (Full Story)

Meanwhile, a University of Michigan survey showed U.S. consumer sentiment fell to its lowest level in more than a decade in early February amid expectations that inflation would continue to rise in the near term. (Full Story)

The CBOE volatility index .VIX, Wall Street's fear gauge, moved up for a second session, after hitting its lowest level since mid-January on Wednesday.

At 10:30 a.m. ET, the Dow Jones Industrial Average .DJI was up 144.18 points, or 0.41%, at 35,385.77, the S&P 500 .SPX was up 6.16 points, or 0.14%, at 4,510.24, and the Nasdaq Composite .IXIC was down 15.16 points, or 0.11%, at 14,170.49.

Despite the recent bout of volatility in markets, the three major indexes are on track for weekly gains, helped by strong earnings, reduction in COVID-19 cases and lifting of mask mandates in some states.

Visa V.N and Mastercard MA.N rose 0.7% and 0.6% respectively after UBS raised its price target on the stocks.

Online real-estate platform Zillow Group Inc ZG.O jumped 15.9% after beating Wall Street estimates for quarterly sales, boosted by an 11-fold increase in revenue in its homes segment. (Full Story)

Under Armour Inc UAA.N slumped 9.5% after warning that its profit margin would be under pressure in the current quarter. (Full Story)

Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a 2.22-to-1 ratio on the NYSE and a 2.02-to-1 ratio on the Nasdaq.

The S&P index recorded six new 52-week highs and two new lows, while the Nasdaq recorded 23 new highs and 48 new lows.


(Reporting by Bansari Mayur Kamdar in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

(( BansariMayur.Kamdar@thomsonreuters.com ;))
